Quotitien

Definition

Scalar α∈R,

Vector x∈Rn,n∈N

Linearity f:Rn↦Rm, f(α⋅x+β⋅y)=α⋅f(x)+β⋅f(y)

Estimator

Bias bias(y^​)=E(y^​)−y y^​ unbiased if bias(y^​)=0

Mean Squared Error MSE=E((y^​−y)2)=bias(y^​)2+Var(y^​)

minimizing the mean squared error = maximum likelihood estimator

Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse X+=α→0lim​(XTX+αI)−1XT

Probability

P(y,x) represent the probability of x and y hanppend.

P(y∣x) represent the probability of y while x already known been happend.

Conditional Probability P(y∣x)=P(x)P(y,x)​

If x independent with y, then P(y∣x)=P(y),P(y∣x)=P(y,x)

Bayes's Rule P(x∣y)=P(y)P(x)P(y∣x)​

Experience E(xi​)=i∑​P(xi​)xi​

E(x)=∫I​P(x)xdx

Variance Var(x)=E((x−E(x))2)

Covariance Cov(x,y)=E((x−E(x))(y−E(y)))

Normal Distribution N(μ,σ2)=2πσ21​​e−2σ21​(⋅−μ)2 If x∼N(μ,σ2), then E(x)=μ, Var(x)=σ2.

Logistic sigmoid s(x)=1+e−x1​

Softplus function ζ(x)=log(1+ex)

Softmax σ(x)i​=∑j​exj​exi​​

Lp norm ∣∣x∣∣p​=(i∑​∣xi​∣p)p1​

XOR

Linear model cannot perform XOR operation f(x,W,c,w,b)=wT⋅max(0,WTx+c)+b f⎝⎜⎜⎜⎛​⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​0011​0101​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎞​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​0110​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​ W=[11​11​],c=[0−1​],w=[1−2​],b=0

General Problem

For a data-set with N samples (xi​,yi​)∈Rn×Rm,i∈N, f:Rn↦Rm y^​=f(x) ∣∣y^​−y∣∣22​=i∑​(y^​i​−yi​)2

Linear Case

Module x∈Rn, w∈Rn×Rm, y∈Rm, b∈Rm,

y^​=f(x)=x⋅w+b

Likelihood function

Likelihood is the probability that a particular outcome x is observed when the true value of the parameter is θ, L(θ∣x)=pθ​(x)=Pθ​(X=x)

Unlike probabilities, likelihood function do not have to integrate (or sum) to 1.

Quadratic Problem

F(x)=21​xwxT−bx

∇F(x)=xw−b

∇2F(x)=w

w is invertable,

x1​=x0​−∇F(x0​)(∇2F(x0​))−1=x0​−(x0​w−b)w−1=bw−1=x∗

w^=wargmin​S(w)

summary

  • maximum likelihood estimation
  • least square regression
  • minimum cross-entropy between the distributions
  • minimum the KL divergence

prevent overfitting

  • maximum a posteriori estimation
  • regularized least square

cross-entropy = negative log-likelihood of a Bernoulli or softmax distribution

PCA

  • maximize variance of data after projection

maximize variance -- lagrangian multiplier --> eigenvector of covariance matrix

Entropy

Definition

For a discrete probability distribution p on the finite set {x1​,x2​,…,xN​} with pi​=p(xi​), the entropy of p is defined as h(p)=−i=1∑N​pi​logpi​.

For a continuous probability density function p on an interval [a,b], the entropy of p is defined as h(p)=−∫ab​p(x)logp(x)dx.

Theorem

For a probability density function p on a finite set {x1​,x2​,…,xN​}, then h(p)≤logn, with equality iff. p is uniform, i.e. ∀i≤N,p(xi​)=1/n.

Theorem

For a continuous probability density function p on R with variance σ2, then h(p)≤21​(1+log(2πσ2)) with equality iff. p if Gaussian with variance σ2, i.e. for some μ we have p(x)=2π​σ1​e−2σ2(x−μ)2​.

Theorem

For a continuous probability density function p on (0,∞) with mean λ, then h(p)≤1+λ, with equality iff. p is exponential with mean λ, i.e. p(x)=λ1​e−λ1​x.

Probability density function

Entropy

H(X)=−x∈X∑​P(x)logP(x) Uniform probability yields maximum uncertainty and therefore maximum entropy.

Cross entropy

The cross entropy of the distribution q relative to a distribution p over a given set is defined as follows: H(p,q)=−Ep​[logq]=−∑plogq=H(p)+DKL​(p∥q)

Kullback-Leibler divergence

The Kullback-Leibler divergence (relative entropy) was introduced as the directed divergence between two distributions DKL​(P∥Q)=−x∈X∑​P(x)log(P(x)Q(x)​)

The Kullback-Leibler divergence is then interpreted as the average difference of the number of bits required for encoding samples of P using a code optimized for Q rather than one optimized for P.

Jensen-Shannon divergence

DJS​(P∥Q)=21​DKL​(P∥M)+21​DKL​(Q∥M) where M=21​(P+Q)

Newton's Method

Given a twice differentiable function f:R→R, solve the optimization problem x∈Rmin​f(x). Consider the second-order Taylor expansion of f around xk​ f(xk​+t)≈f(xk​)+f′(xk​)t+21​f′′(xk​)t2. Setting the derivative to zero, 0=dtd​(f(xk​)+f′(xk​)t+21​f′′(xk​)t2)=f′(xk​)+f′′(xk​)t, the minimum is achieved for t=−f′′(xk​)f′(xk​)​, then xk+1​=xk​+t=xk​−f′′(xk​)f′(xk​)​.

Regression

Linear Regression

Objective function wmin​(∥y−x⋅w∥22​) Ordinary least square Lagrangian function L(w)=∣∣y−x⋅w∣∣22​=(y−x⋅w)T(y−x⋅w)=yTy−wTxTy−yTxw+wTxTxw ∂w∂L(w)​=2xTxw−2xTy Let ∂L(w)/∂w=0 leads to w=(xTx)−1xTy

With respect to different constraints,

  • ∣∣w∣∣1​<t for lasso,
  • ∣∣w∣∣2​<t for ridge.

Ridge Regression : L1 Regularization

Least absolute shrinkage and selection operator wmin​(∥y−x⋅w∥22​+λ∥w∥1​).

  • When λ=0 , no parameters are eliminated. The estimate is equal to the one found with linear regression.
  • As λ increases, more and more coefficients are set to zero and eliminated (theoretically, when λ=∞, all coefficients are eliminated).
  • As λ increases, bias increases.
  • As λ decreases, variance increases.

Lasso Regression : L2 Regularization

wmin​(∥y−x⋅w∥22​+λ∥w∥22​). L(w)=wTxTxw−wTxTy−yTxw+yTy+λwTw ∂w∂L(w)​=2xTxw−2xTy+2λw Let ∂L(w)/∂w=0 leads to w=(xTx+λI)−1xTy

Elastic net Regularization

wmin​(∥y−x⋅w∥22​+λ2​∥w∥22​+λ1​∥w∥1​).

Logistic Regression

For p∈(0,1), logitp=ln(odds)=ln1−pp​ Logistic function is inverse logit, sigmoid function defined as follows, for q∈(−∞,∞), p=s(q)=logit−1q=eq+1eq​=1+e−q1​ Suppose logity linear with x, i.e. ln1−yy​=β0​+β1​x then y=s(x)=1+e−(β0​+β1​x)1​

Conjugate Descent

Definition

Let Q∈Rn×n be a symmetric matrix. vi​,vj​∈Rn,vi​=vj​=0 are Q-orthogonal w.r.t. Q if viT​Qvj​=0

Proposition

Let Q be positive definite. If v1​,v2​,…,vk​ are Q-orthogonal, then they are linear independent.

Proof

If vk​=α1​v1​+⋯+αk−1​vk−1​, then vkT​Qvk​=vkT​Q(α1​v1​+⋯+αk−1​vk−1​)=α1​vkT​Qv1​+⋯+αk−1​vkT​Qvk−1​=0 controversy with postive definite.

Proposition

Let v1​,v2​,…,vn​∈Rn vectors Q-orthogonal, x0​∈Rn be arbitrary starting point.

Assume αk​=−vkT​Qvk​gkT​vk​​

xk+1​=xk​+αk​vk​

gk​=Qxk​−b

then xn​ is the solution of Qx=b.

x∈Rnmin​21​xTQx−bTx

Matrix Q∈Rn×n is positive definite. Qx=b,x∈Rn Let v1​,v2​,…,vn​∈Rn vectors Q-orthogonal, which is linear independent, then ∀x∗∈Rn there exist α1​,α2​,…,αn​∈R, x∗=i=1∑n​αi​vi​=α1​v1​+α2​v2​+⋯+αn​vn​ viT​Qx∗=viT​Q(α1​v1​+α2​v2​+⋯+αn​vn​)=αi​viT​Qvi​ αi​=viT​Qvi​viT​Qx∗​=viT​Qvi​viT​b​ x∗=i=1∑n​αi​vi​=i=1∑n​viT​Qvi​viT​b​vi​

Proposition

Let x0​∈Rn arbitrary, v0​αk​xk+1​gk​vk+1​βk​​=b−Qx0​=−vkT​Qvk​gkT​vk​​=xk​+αk​vk​=Qxk​−b=−gk+1​+βk​vk​=vkT​Qvk​gk+1T​Qvk​​​

Gradient Descent

Multi-variable function f:Rn↦R, defined differentiable in a neighborhood of a point x∈Rn, for λ∈R+​ small enough, xk+1​=xk​−λ∇f(xk​) leads to f(xk+1​)≤f(xk​).

If f convex and ∇f Lipschitz, fk​ converge to a local mimimum.

Optimization : Momentum

Let γ<1,v0​=0, {xk+1​vk​​=xk​−vk​=γvk−1​+λ∇f(xk​)​ The momentum term increases for dimensions whose gradients point in the same directions and reduces updates for dimensions whose gradients change directions. As a result, we gain faster convergence and reduced oscillation.

Optimization : Nesterov

Version with correction, {xk+1​vk​​=xk​−vk​=γvk−1​+λ∇f(xk​−γvk−1​)​ This anticipatory update prevents us from going too fast and results in increased responsiveness, which has significantly increased the performance of RNNs on a number of tasks.

Adagrad

It adapts the learning rate to the parameters, performing larger updates for infrequent and smaller updates for frequent parameters. For this reason, it is well-suited for dealing with sparse data. xk+1​=xk​−Gk​+ϵ​λ​∇f(xk​) Application : learned to recognize cats in Youtube videos; GloVe word embeddings.

Adadelta

Adadelta is an extension of Adagrad that seeks to reduce its aggressive, monotonically decreasing learning rate. Instead of accumulating all past squared gradients, Adadelta restricts the window of accumulated past gradients to some fixed size w.

RMSprop

RMSprop and Adadelta have both been developed independently around the same time stemming from the need to resolve Adagrad’s radically diminishing learning rates. RMSprop in fact is identical to the first update vector of Adadelta. v(xk​,t):=γv(xk​,t−1)+(1−γ)(∇f(xk​))2 xk+1​=xk​−v(xk​,t)​η​∇f(xk​)

Adam

Adaptive Moment Estimation (Adam) is another method that computes adaptive learning rates for each parameter. In addition to storing an exponentially decaying average of past squared gradients vk​ like Adadelta and RMSprop, Adam also keeps an exponentially decaying average of past gradients uk​, similar to momentum. uk​vk​​=β1​uk−1​+(1−β1​)∇f(xk​)=β2​vk−1​+(1−β2​)∇2f(xk​)​

\begin{split} \hat u_k &= \frac{u_k}{1-\beta_1} \ \hat v_k &= \frac{v_k}{1-\beta_2} \end{split}

xk+1​=xk​−v^k​​+ϵη​∇f(xk​)

Principal Component Analysis

In order to maximize variance, the first weight vector w1​ thus has to satisfy w1​=∥w∥=1argmax​{i∑​(x(i)​⋅w)2}=∥w∥=1argmax​{∥Xw∥2}=∥w∥=1argmax​{wTXTXw} Since w1​ has been defined to be a unit vector, it equivalently also satisfies w1​=argmax{wTwwTXTXw​} The quantity to be maximised can be recognised as a Rayleigh quotient. A standard result for a positive semidefinite matrix such as XTX is that the quotient's maximum possible value is the largest eigenvalue of the matrix, which occurs when w is the corresponding eigenvector.

Let x∈Rn be origin samples, projection vector w satisfies wTw=1. Denote Σ=N1​(X−Xˉ)(X−Xˉ)T the variance of origin samples, variance of projected samples, σ(X,w)=N1​(wTX−wTXˉ)(wTX−wTXˉ)T=wTΣw

Lagrangian multiplier form, maxwTΣw+λ(1−wTw), leads to Σw=λw. the variance σ(X,w) is maximized with w is the eigenvector of Σ, the maximum value is the related eigenvalue λ.

PCA is either done by

  • singular value decomposition of a design matrix;
  • eigenvalue decomposition on the covariance matrix.

Eigenvalue Decomposition

A (non-zero) vector v∈Rn is an eigenvector of a square matrix A∈Rn×Rn if it satisfies the linear equation Av=λv where λ∈R termed the eigenvalue corresponding to v.

Since ∀i∈N,

Avi​=λvi​,

A[v1​​v2​​⋯​vn​​]=[v1​​v2​​⋯​vn​​]⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​λ1​​λ2​​⋱​λn​​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​

AV=VΛ

Diagonalisable matrice A can be factorized as A=VΛV−1 where Λii​=λi​ and vi​ is the i-th column of V.

Singualar Value Decomposition

The singular value decomposition (svd) of matrix A∈Rn×Rm A=UΣWT where U∈Rn×Rn, W∈Rm×Rm and Σ∈Rn×Rm is diagonal with positive number. ATA=WΣTUTUΣWT=WΣ2WT The right singular vectors W of A the eigenvectors of XTX, while the singular values of A are equal to the square-root of the eigenvalues of XTX.

Support Vector Machine

Suppose dataset xi​∈Rn related to label yi​∈{+1,−1}, find w∈Rn and bias b∈R such that {xi​⋅w+b≥+1,yi​xi​⋅w+b≤−1,yi​​=+1=−1​ which leads to yi​(xi​⋅w+b)≥+1.

The distance between optimal hyperplanes is 2/∣∣w∣∣, so maximizing the margin equals to minimizing ∣∣w∣∣.

Primary problem : min Lp​(w,αi​), Lp​(w,αi​)=21​∣∣w∣∣2−i∑n​αi​yi​(xi​⋅w+b)+i∑n​αi​ s.t. ∀i,αi​≥0, w=i∑n​αi​yi​xi​,i∑n​αi​yi​=0.

Dual problem : max Ld​(αi​), Ld​(αi​)=i∑n​αi​−21​i,j∑n​αi​αj​yi​yj​(xi​⋅xj​) s.t. ∀i,αi​≥0, i∑n​αi​yi​=0.

Only support vectors have nonzero coefficients αi​.

Approaches : sub-gradient descent and coordinate descent.

Fourier series

Complex form

For 2L-periodic function f, f(t)=k=−∞∑∞​ck​eikt⋅π/L where ck​=2L1​⟨f(t),eikt⋅π/L⟩=2L1​∫−LL​f(t)e−ikt⋅π/Ldt

From complex to real

Since eiθ=cosθ+isinθ, suppose ck​=ak​+ibk​,ak​,bk​∈R, then f(t)==​k=−∞∑∞​(ak​+ibk​)(cos(kt⋅π/L)+isin(kt⋅π/L))(a0​+ib0​)+k=1∑∞​(ak​+ibk​)(cos(kt⋅π/L)+isin(kt⋅π/L))+k=1∑∞​(a−k​+ib−k​)(cos(−kt⋅π/L)+isin(−kt⋅π/L))​ if f(t)∈R, ak​=a−k​ and bk​=−b−k​ which means ck​=ck​ˉ​, then f(t)=a0​+k=1∑∞​(2ak​)cos(kt⋅π/L)+(−2bk​)sin(kt⋅π/L))

Real value, conventional form

For 2π-periodic function f, f(t)=2a0​​+k=1∑∞​(ak​cos(kt)+bk​sin(kt))

where

ak​=∣∣cos(kt)∣∣21​⟨f(t),cos(kt)⟩=π1​∫−ππ​f(t)cos(kt)dt bk​=∣∣sin(kt)∣∣21​⟨f(t),sin(kt)⟩=π1​∫−ππ​f(t)sin(kt)dt

From fourier series to fourier transform

f(t)=k=−∞∑∞​(2L1​∫−LL​f(x)e−ikx⋅π/Ldx)⋅eikt⋅π/L

Since ∫−∞∞​f(t)dt=L→∞lim​k=−∞∑∞​Lπ​f(k⋅Lπ​)

which leads,

f(t)​=L→∞lim​k=−∞∑∞​(2L1​∫−LL​f(x)e−ikx⋅π/L⋅eikt⋅π/Ldx)=2π1​L→∞lim​k=−∞∑∞​Lπ​(∫−LL​f(x)e−ikx⋅π/L⋅eikt⋅π/Ldx)=2π1​∫−∞∞​(∫−∞∞​f(x)e−ix⋅ξ⋅eit⋅ξdx)dξ=2π1​∫−∞∞​(∫−∞∞​f(x)e−ix⋅ξdx)eit⋅ξdξ​

Denote (Fourier transform) f^​(ξ)=∫−∞∞​f(x)e−ix⋅ξdx then (Inverse Fourier transform) f(t)=2π1​∫−∞∞​f^​(ξ)eit⋅ξdξ

this is non-unitary, angular frequency form.

Descrete Fourier Transform

Multiresolution

Definition. L2(R)

L2(R)={f:R↦C∣∫R​∣f(x)∣2dx<∞}

Definition. Multiresolution Analysis

A multiresolution analysis for L2(R) consists of

  • a sequence of closed subspaces (Vj​)j∈Z​ of L2(R), and
  • a scaling function ϕ∈V0​ ,

such that the following conditions holds,

  • {ϕ(⋅−k)}k∈Z​ constitute an orthonomal basis of V0​.
  • ∀i∈Z,Vj−1​⊂Vj​,
  • ∪Vj​​=L2(R),
  • ∩Vj​={0},
  • f∈V0​⟺f(2j⋅)∈Vj​,

The scaling function ϕ in multiresolution analysis determines the spaces Vj​ uniquely.

Definition. Wavelet space

For any j∈Z, let Wj​ denote the orthogonal complement of Vj​ with respect to Vj+1​, i.e. Wj​={f∈Vj+1​∣⟨f,g⟩=0,∀g∈Vj​}.

For each j∈Z, the closed subspaces, Vj​=Vj−1​⊕Wj−1​=⋯⊕Wj−2​⊕Wj−1​

Any wavelet generate a direct sum decomposition of L2(R).

Basis for Vj​, {ϕkj​=2j/2ϕ(2jx−k)}k∈Z​

ϕ(x)=∑k∈Z​pk​ϕ(2x−k)

ϕlj−1​=2−1/2∑k∈Z​pk−2l​ϕkj​

Basis for Wj​, {ψkj​=2j/2ψ(2jx−k)}k∈Z​

ψ(x)=∑k∈Z​(−1)kpl−k​​ψ(2x−k)

ψlj−1​=2−1/2∑k∈Z​(−1)kp1−(k−2l)​​ψkj​

Decomposition formulas

Denote fkj​=⟨f,ϕkj​⟩ and gkj​=⟨f,ψkj​⟩, {flj−1​=2−1/2∑k​pk−2l​​fkj​,glj−1​=2−1/2∑k​(−1)kp1−(k−2l)​fkj​,​

Reconstruction formulas

fkj​=l∑​pk−2l​flj−1​+l∑​(−1)kp1−(k−2l)​​glj−1​

Proposition.

The function ϕ∈L2(R) generate a multiresolution analysis. Let ψ∈L2(R) and {ψ(⋅−k)}k∈Z​ is an orthonormal basis for W0​, then

  • the functions {ψ(2j⋅−k)}k∈Z​ form an orthonormal basis for Wj​,
  • ψ is wavelet, i.e., the functions {ψ(2j⋅−k)}j,k∈Z​ form an orthonormal basis for Wj​,
  • the functions {ϕ(⋅−k)}k∈Z​∪{ψ(2j⋅−k)}j∈N,k∈Z​ form an orthonormal basis for L2(R).

Proposition.

The function ϕ∈L2(R) generate a multiresolution analysis. Then there exist a 1-periodic function H∈L2(0,1) such that ϕ^​(2t)=H(t)ϕ^​(t),t∈R. where H(t)=k∈R∑​ck​e2πikt

Let G(t)=H(t+21​)​e−2πit define the function ψ ψ^​(2t)=G(t)ϕ^​(t) then

  • the functions {ψ(2j⋅−k)}k∈Z​ form an orthonormal basis for Wj​,
  • ψ is wavelet, i.e., the functions {ψ(2j⋅−k)}j,k∈Z​ form an orthonormal basis for Wj​,

G(t)=H(t+21​)​e−2πit=k∈R∑​cˉk​e−2πik(t+21​)−2πit

Proposition

If G(t)=k∈R∑​dk​e2πikt then ψ(x)=2k∈Z∑​dk​ϕ(2x+k),x∈R.

Compactly supported wavelet means that only few coeficients of dk​ are non-zeros.

Let ϕ∈L2(R), {ϕ(⋅−k)}k∈Z​ is an orthonormal system iff. k∈Z∑​∣ϕ^​(t+k)∣2=1,t∈R.

publication

傅立叶分析 Fourier Analysis

基础知识

掌握傅立叶分析需要了解以下概念：

  • 向量空间 (vector space)
  • 线性 (linearity)
  • 向量基 (base/basis)

内积

离散向量 x,y∈CN 的内积定义为 ⟨x,y⟩=j=1∑N​xj​yˉ​j​.

连续函数 f,g∈L2(R) 的内积定义为

⟨f,g⟩=∫fgˉ​.

注意理解离散求和符号 ∑ 和连续求和符号 ∫ 在概念上的一致性。

正交基

如果 B 是向量空间 H 的一组正交基，那么对于所有向量 ∀x∈H, x=b∈B∑​⟨b,b⟩⟨x,b⟩​b=b∈B∑​∣∣b∣∣2⟨x,b⟩​b.

一般将 ∣∣b∣∣2⟨x,b⟩​ 部分叫做向量的坐标。

注意同一向量空间可能有不同的基，所以对应不同的坐标。

在二维平面 R2 中，经典基向量为 v1​=(1,0) 和 v2​=(0,1)，他们组成的变换矩阵为单位矩阵 (identity matrix)

[10​01​]

假设我们选取 u1​=(1,1) 和 u2​=(−1,1) 作为新的一组基， 因为 ⟨u1​,u2​⟩=0, 这是一组正交基，他们组成的变换矩阵为

T=21​[1−1​11​]

这里我们并没有对向量进行归一化处理，所以在变换矩阵或逆变换矩阵里一般会有一个系数， 这也是在傅立叶变换的定义中有不同系数版本的原因。

任意二维平面上的向量 (x,y)∈R2 都可以通过基 u1​,u2​ 的线性组合表示， 向量在该坐标系中的坐标可以通过变换矩阵得到 21​[1−1​11​][xy​]

可以看出， (1,1) 变换后的坐标为 (1,0)，因为 (1,1)=21​(1⋅u1​+0⋅u2​)， (0,1) 变换后的坐标为 (1,1)，因为 (0,1)=21​(1⋅u1​+1⋅u2​).

从坐标系 (u1​,u2​) 变换回 (v1​,v2​) 的逆变换矩阵也即矩阵 T 的逆矩阵为 T−1=[11​−11​]

总结而言，矩阵 T 可以进行坐标变换，同时其逆矩阵 T−1 可以实现坐标逆变换，

I=T−1T=([11​−11​])⋅(21​[1−1​11​])

离散傅立叶变换

现实场景下的信号处理一般针对离散数据而言， 长度为 n 的离散数据可以当作 n 维向量空间中的向量, 假定它在经典基向量下的坐标为 x=(x0​,x1​,x2​,…,xn−1​)∈Cn.

这里我们考虑一组新的基向量 (v0​,v1​,…,vn−1​)， 注意 vk​∈Cn 是一个 n 维向量。 假定这是一组正交基，那么记

V=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​v0​v1​⋮vn−1​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​∈Cn×n

则 V⋅x 表示向量 x 在变换后的向量。 注意这里的 V 是 n×n 的矩阵。

假设矩阵 V 是可逆的，它的逆矩阵记做 V−1，那么我们有

I=V−1V

对于所有的向量 x∈Cn，

(V−1V)⋅x=V−1⋅(Vx)=x

这样我们可以将 x′=Vx 叫做 x 的 ～变换，而 x=V−1x′ 叫做 x 的 ～逆变换。

当采用如下的基向量时，我们得到了离散条件下的 傅立叶变换 和 傅立叶逆变换， vk​=(e−2πik⋅0/n,e−2πik⋅1/n,…,e−2πik⋅(n−1)/n)

这里 e 为欧拉 Euler 常数，eiθ=cosθ+isinθ，所以 k 为整数时 e2πik=1，当 k=l/n 为时可以理解为 1 的 n 次方根的第 l 个根。

k 的取值为从 0 到 n−1 共 n 个向量，注意到

⟨vk​,vl​⟩=n⋅δk,l​

也即这是一组正交向量，证明可以参考内积的定义进行展开计算。

基向量 vk​ 的选取非常巧妙，也是傅立叶变换的精髓，可以这样理解， 对于 n 维空间，选取 1 的 n 个 n 次方根作为一个基向量，然后通过分别取 0 到 n−1 次方构建出一组正交基。

记 ω=e−2πi/n, 基向量 vk​=(ω0,ωk,ω2k…,ω(n−1)k)， 傅立叶变换的矩阵为 Fn​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​11⋮1​1ω⋮ωn−1​1ω2⋮ω2(n−1)​⋯⋯⋱⋯​1ω(n−1)⋮ω(n−1)(n−1)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​

傅立叶逆变换的矩阵为 F^n​=n1​⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​11⋮1​1ωˉ⋮ωˉn−1​1ωˉ2⋮ωˉ2(n−1)​⋯⋯⋱⋯​1ωˉ(n−1)⋮ωˉ(n−1)(n−1)​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​

由此可见，傅立叶变换的矩阵或者说基向量的精髓之处在于它的逆矩阵可以如此轻而易举地计算或者说构造出来。

至此，对于任意长度为 n 的向量 x，如果它表示的是时域的信号， 那么可以通过 Fn​x 计算它的傅立叶变换 x′，得到频域上的信号表示， 在频域上对信号进行适当处理之后再通过 F^n​x′ 重新得到时域上被修改过的信号。 频域上的修改会对时域上的信号有怎样的影响已经超出了本文的范畴，推荐信号处理相关书籍。

通过如下的计算可以看出在计算傅立叶变换时可通过分治的思想将 计算复杂度从 O(n2) 降到 O(logn)，这也快速傅立叶变换 (FFT) 在工程上如此成功的理论基础。 x^k​=j=0∑n−1​ωjkxj​=j=0∑n−1​ω2jkx2j​+j=0∑n−1​ω2jk+kx2j+1​=j=0∑n−1​ω2jkx2j​+ωkj=0∑n−1​ω2jkx2j+1​

至此我们从向量空间的角度理解了离散傅立叶变换，后续的文章我们继续从离散情况出发推广字连续有界 （傅立叶级数 Fourier Series）和连续（傅立叶变换 Fourier Transform）的情况。
